DIV1.P: THE REPRESENTATION OF THE Lower House of Convocaion of the English Clergy EXAMINED: BEING REMARKS ON THE Present State of Religion NOW IN ENGLAND.
Printed at London, and Re-Printed at Edinburgh by J. Moncur. 1711.

DIV1.HEAD: THE REPRESENTATION OF THE Lower House of Convocation of the English-Clergy Examined, &c.
DIV1.P: THE Pious Zeal and just Concern of the Re∣verend Members of the Lower House of Convocation, express'd against the late Ex∣cessive Growth of Infidelity, Heresy, and Pro∣phaneness, in their late Representation, and otherwise, can never be sufficiently Commended, or Encouraged. It is hoped no Reader of these Remarks, will be so Uncharitable to imagine, that we are entring the Lists against the Convo∣cation, in Defence of the aforesaid Abhor'd and Abominable Crimes of Infidelity, Heresie and Pro∣faneness.

I shall not either, concern these Papers in any part of the Reasons given by the Right Reverend the Upper House of Convocation, for their dis∣agreeing with the Lower House in the said Re∣presentation, which in the Title of the Repre∣sentation is called Rejecting it by the Ʋpper-House;
otherwise than just to Note in Defence of the said Upper House; that however I do not enquire what their Lordships Reasons were for the said Dis∣agreeing with the Lower House, which I doubt not were very good, it may yet be allow'd to say Negatively what they were not, (viz.) Not for any want of Zeal in their Lordships against the aforesaid Crimes, or that their Lordships were in the least willing to Favour or Encourage Infide∣lity, Heresie or Prophaneness, which they are very sensible, have of late excessively increased in these Nations, and which they have on all occasions given Testimony both of their Concern about, and their Zeal against: Nor was it, as is hum∣bly advanc'd in their Lordship's behalf, that they, the Upper House, should not be very willing upon all Occasions to join in a regular manner, and as far as they think their Duty, with the Lower House, in duly Representing to Her Majesty the State of Religion, with respect as well to these, as all other Evils that obstruct the Growth of the true Christian Religion in these Nations; altho' they could not join in the several Additions, as well as some Circumstances in the manner, which their Lordships thought they had just Reason to dislike in the said Repre∣sentation.

If any Man pleases to Revise the Two Differ∣ing Representations as they are Published, and as they both passed in the respective House of Convocation, they need not be at much Difficul∣ty to find out the Point in which the Two Houses Disagreed. And tho' the said Disagreement is perhaps the Principal Reason why the said Re∣presentations were respectively printed, by way of Appeal to the World; and to give them op∣portunity
to judge of the said Difference; yet I shall rather take notice of some things wherein the said Representatation differs from the true State of Religion in England, which it is said to Represent, than of such things wherein it differs from the Opinion of the Upper House. Nor shall I take this by way of Paragraph, as if we were going to give a particular Answer to the Repre∣sentation, but rather Examine, agreeable to our Title, what is the true State of Religion in this Nation in the Case Repreented; and say some∣thing, which, had the Reverend Convocation look'd with an Impartial Eye, into the Circumstan∣ces of the Church, they would have seen great Cause to have added in the Body of their Re∣presentation, or to have alter'd the Substance of it, so as that it might have Included these things with (or perhaps instead of) some of those on which they lay the Great Stress of their humble Complaint.

All Men will grant the Truth of the first Asser∣tion in the Representation, (viz.) that “a De∣luge of Impiety and Licentiousness hath broken in upon us, and overspread the Face of this Church and Kingdom, and also that this is Mat∣ter of Unspeakable Grief.”

But it is humbly Referr'd to the Consideration of all Impartial Men, that the Source of this De∣luge is not thorowly Traced by the Convoca∣tion; and that had the Reverend Members of the Committee not fainted in their Search, they might have gone much farther back than the late Rebellion, and indeed might have come to a full stop, even at the Native, True, Undoubted Spring, and Original, to which we all owe the Progress of Satan's Kingdom, and the Mon∣strous
Eruption of all manner of Wickedness i the Nation.

This the Reverend Committee seems to own themselves sensible of, when in speaking of the Source aforesaid, they say with great Modesty▪ as far back as we have Trac'd it, signifying, tha they could have Trac'd it farther back; bu being rather willing to have it fix'd upon those Times, than Convinc'd that it ought not to b look'd for somewhere else, they set down thi for its Original; reserving nevertheless a Doo of Escape at this Cautious Parenthesis, (as fa back as we have Trac'd it.) To which it had been very happy, if they had thought fit to have sub subjoin'd some Reasons, as no doubt they ha many very good ones to produce, why they Traced it no farther.

This had serv'd to Silence those Unquiet Pha naticks, who alledge that the Convocation have been Partial in fixing the Source of our Impiety and Licentiousness at a wrong Period, in order to blacken their Party, and the Times when they had the Reins in their hands; while they (th Convocation) knew the true Spring of them lay father back, where they did not care to look and that they did not Trace it back farther, for fear of finding it where it was, and therefore look for it, where it was not. At the same time giving no other Reason why they place the sai Source of our Evil there, than this, viz. (not that they could not) but that have not Traced farther back.

Wherefore I humbly crave leave to Remar that in Justice to Truth, the Reverend the Comittee of the Convocation, ought, and in Dut to the Nature of a True Representation, we
oblig'd, besides their Debt of Sincerity to their Sovereign, before whom they were laying the True State of Religion in this Nation, to have Trac'd the Deluge of these Impieties, not to a Supposed, but to a True and Real Source. And I think, with Submission, that it is not a sufficient Evidence to prove the Source of those Impieties is ound in the late long unnatural Rebellion, to say that they have Trac'd it no farther, since by that Rule, for any thing that appears in this Represen∣ation, the said Source may be any where else, s well as there; and perhaps may be somewhere e and not there.

And that I may with the most Impartial Care ther Represent the Injustice of this placing our pieties at the Period aforesaid, it is humbly ffered, That the true Source of all this Deluge of piety, is rather to be plac'd at that Wretched Unhappy Time, when Iniquity was Estab∣ed by a Law; when the Sword of Authority, ish God for the terror of Evil doers, had put in∣the Hands of the Supreme Magistrate, and which he ought not to have born in vain, being trusted by his Sovereign Lord and Maker, to Hands of King J—s the First, for the Pur∣es aforesaid, was Employ'd by him against the d that gave him that Authority; and was de an Encourager, and Maintainer of, (nay n a Compeller of his Subjects by Violence to) manner of Impiety and Licentiousnes; particu∣ by the Publishing that Impious, Licentious, d by all good Christians, Adhor'd Proclamation the Profanation of the Lord's Day, called the BOOK OF SPORTS; Condemning as Puri∣s, Phanaticks, and Schismaticks, and turning of their Livings all those Godly, Pious and
Learned Ministers of the Church of England ▪ who refused to joyn in that War Proclaim'd SSgainst Heaven, by Reading, against their Consci∣ences, that Impious and Abominable Book their Churches.

Till this Time the Church of England, and the Kimgdom of England, as the Representation say well, was Eminent for Purity of Faith, and Sobri∣ty of Manners. But from this time forward, sh grew Noted for Corruption in both.

By this wicked Contrivance, the shame and Disgrace of that Reign, the Morals of the Nation were entirely Debauch'd. and God's Holy D Prophaned by the King's Commandment. Then was, that the Poor People were set to Sports and Pastimes, on the Day, in which God had Com∣manded that we should do no manner of Work. if when our Lawful Employments were forbiden us, Games and Sports could yet be made Lawful. Then et was that the most Impious Licen was given by the King, that ever was heard of this Nation, and which no Christian Nation the World can shew the Parallel to. Where of Pleasurers were the Exercise of God's Holy Day in defiance of his Express Prohibition, and Con∣tempt of his Gracious Invitation to the stri Observance of that Day, in that Remakable Te Isa: 58. 13. 14. If thou turn away thy foot from Sabbath, from doing thy Pleasure on my Holy day and call the Sabbath a delight, the holy of the Lord honourable, and shalt honour him, not doing thi own ways, nor finding thine own pleasure, nor speing thine own words. Then shalt thou delight self in the Lord, and I will cause thee to ride up the high places of the Earth, and feed thee with the heritage of Jacob thy Father; for the mouth the Lord hath spoken it.

Instead of these strict observings of the Sab∣bath, the foreaid Impious Proclamation pulls down the Sacred Sense of God's Command, and lays the Sabbath open to the Licentious and A∣bominable Practise of Sport and Pastimes; giving License to the People to meet together for the profess'd Publick horrid Insulting of their Mak∣er in these very words.

“Our Pleasure likewise is that after the end of Divine Service, our good People be not Dis∣turbed, Letted or Discouraged from any Law∣ful Recreations on Sundays, or other Holidays; such as Dancing, Men or Women, archery Leaping Vaulting: nor from having may Games, Whitson-ales, and Morrie Dancing and setting up May-poles, and other Sports there∣with used, so as the same be had in Convenient time, without Impediment or neglect of Di∣vine Service. Vid. Book of Sports, P. 6.”
We should cause more of this to be Quoted but that the thing is so abominable, it seems grie∣vous to write, and a Melancholly thing to be handed down to Posterity.

Let our Reverend Fathers of the Convocation be Judges for the Justice of this present Remon∣strance, that this is the most palpable period of time; and indeed the only one to which the Source of the Great Deluge of Impiety and Li∣centiousness that is broke in upon us ought to be trac'd. Nor can they Adjourn the beginning of those things from this time, to the late Ʋnnatural Rebellion, unless it be, because that K. Ch—s I. the Son of the aforesaid King Ja—s renew'd the same
War against Heaven, which his Father had wickedly begun, by Reprinting the said Procla∣mation, and adding his own Authority to renew those Sports and Pastimes, in the Ninth Year of his Reign; which abominable Practise was not, as may be justly thought, the least occasion of the dreadful Plague of Civil War, and Rebellion which broke out in a few Years after, and which ended in the Destruction of that King, and for a while in the Subversion of the Government.

I can not therefore but referr back to those Miserable Times, when all manner of Wicked∣ness, Profaness, Contempt of God, and of his Sabbath, broke in upon this Nation, partly by the Connivance, and partly by the open Autho∣rity of the Crown.

From this wicked Practice we can not won∣der, if either on the one hand, Licentious People the restraint of the Law being taken away, took their ful Liberty to provoke God with open Im∣moralities, or that the Enemies of Revealed Re∣ligion took an Advantage from hence to mock and make a jest of Religion in General; or that all manner of Error crept in, where so gross an Error led the way, under the shelter of Royal Authority.

From hence began the General Debauching of the Clergy of the Church of England; the Sober, Pious, Diligent and Learned Ministers being every where Turn'd out of their Livings; which they willingly and chearfully forsook, rather than Submit to Read that Abominable Book in their Churches which they foresaw would be the Source of all Impiety and Licentiousness (the Con∣vocations own words) and likewise to be found in Mr. Perkins Reason of the Separation of the Puritans, pag. 16.

It was, says that good Old Christian, an inex∣pressible Grief of Soul to those good Men, to see the same Pulpits, where they had with Labour, Conscience, and Diligence Unweari∣ed, Preached to their People the Sound Do∣ctrines of the Gospel of Christ, and thundred out the Curses of God's Righteous Law a∣gainst Sabbath-Breakers, Riotous Persons, and Profaners of God's Holy Ordinances, made the Trumpetters to Proclaim Satan's King∣dom, to License what God had strictly for∣bidden, under Severe Comination, and the People Invited to Wickedness from the same Places, and by the Mouths of the same Mi∣nisters that used to Invite them to Holiness, and Christian Purity; and therefore many good Men chose to Suffer the loss of their Livings, and forsake their Churches; which were now become the Source of Impiety and Licentiousness.

How unhappy now was it for our Convocati∣on, that being to Represent to Her Majesty the State of Religion, in their Enquiry into, and Search after the Source of Impiety and Profane∣ness, they should stop short at the late Rebellion, never look back to the true beginning of the thing, and FOB Her Majesty off, only with tel∣ling Her, they have Traced it no farther; which any body might have known without their tel∣ing it, upon a bare looking over the Represen∣tation.

Now suppose Her Majesty should have said to them, in Answer to their Representation, some∣thing like this, which I must own, they might seen a great deal of Reason to have expected from their Sovereign.
Gentlemen,

“I Am equally Grieved when I Reflect on that Deluge of Impiety and Licentiousness which hath broke in upon us, and approve very well of your Tracing it to its true Source. But I Ob∣serve you say as far back as you have Traced it. I hope you have Traced it as far back as you ca that the real Original of it may be discover'd without which I think no stop can be put to it farther breaking in upon us.”

Had Her Majesty been pleased to say any thing like this to the Clergy, when they had Present∣ed their Representation (if they had Presente it) I cannot but with some Amazement Reflect on what the Gentlemen would ha' said for them∣selves, and I think they could have only Answer it one of these ways.

LIST.ITEM: 1. Sullenly, Why really, Madam, we have Trac'd it no farther and think that is far e∣nough. Or,
2. Ingenuously Madam, we Humbly ask Your Majesties Pardon, that we have not Trac'd it farther; and we will according to Your Majesties Direction, go on, to Search and Trace it to the bottom: Or,

3. Honestly, Truly, Madam, this was the most proper Period for our Purpose, as suited best the Design we had in view, (Viz.) to blacken that Party of Your Majesties Sub∣jects, we aim at; and as we were conscious that looking farther back would have fix' it, where we are not willing to have found.

DIV1.P:
As I have plac'd the true Source of the Gre Duge of Impiety and Licentiousness at the Priod of the Book of Sports, it would necessari
call me to lay down the True State of the Nati∣on's Morals before, (and unto) that very time; as also to Enquire into the State of Religion and Morality from that time; both which would Il∣lustrate the Point that I am upon, (Viz.) That the True Original and Source of our Impiety and Licentiousness is to be most justly placed here. But the other Absurdities of this Representation, call me off from this needful Work, so that I can but just touch upon it.

What the State of Religion in England was at that time, cannot be better expressed, than in the words of the Representation it self, (Viz.) That England was Eminent for Purity of Faith, and Sobriety of Manners. This was Evident, from the blameless Lives, and sound Principles of those Eminent Divines of the Church of England, who were overwhelmed by the First Eruption of this said Deluge of Impiety and Licentiousness; and as I quoted before, were cast out of their Li∣vings, because they could not consent to swim down the strong Current of Impiety and Licen∣tiousness which then ran through the Kingdom, and bore down all before it.

These were the Champions of God, and of the Church of England, the very Seed of the Mar∣tyrs in the Reign before, sprung up in Queen Elizabeth's Long and Happy Reign, and Ripen∣ed to a Perfection never since known in this Na∣tion, These were they, for whom Erasmus, when he came into England, entertain'd such a Veneration; that being Enquired of when he came back to Holland, of the State of Religion in England; and giving an account of Persons, as well as Things, after he had spoken favourably enough too of other People; but, says he, Sit
Anima Mea cum Puritanis Anglicanis; may my Soul Rest with the Souls of the English Puritans.

Upon the Death of the Famous Queen Eliza∣beth, the Patron of the English Church; with the Scots Court came in all manner of Disoluteness, Prophaneness and Immorality; which, that it might spread over the whole Nation, the King began early, and even at his first Coming, Pub∣lished this Abominable Proclamation for the Pro∣fanation of Gods Holy Day.

What the Morals of the King himself were, I need do no more than referr the Reader to Coke's Detection, Vol. I. where a large Account is gi∣ven of the Methods by which the Court Endea∣vour'd to Debauch the Morals of the People. As to the King himself, those Devout Christians, who put up their daily Prayers in his House of Revels, now the Royal Chappel, can not when they cast up their Eyes Ejaculatorily to Heaven, but see the Image of the Sovereign of those Times, Crown'd with Garlands, and Celebrat∣ing the Baccanalian Triumphs of Drunkenness and Debauchery. And as this Roof was Painted by the Curious Hand of the Famous Titian, he has Represented Things and Persons so to the Life, that there needs no Workman to come af∣ter him, to describe those Drunken Days.

From this Time, Strictness of Life, Eminence for Piety, for Doctrine, and for Diligence, grew daily more and more out of Fashion; and if any Mi∣nister of the Church of England, distinguish'd himself by his Exactness of Conversation, or Zea∣lous Preaching against the Vices of the Times, he became Contemptible among the People, was Reproached with being Precise, and Branded with what they then thought Infamous, (Viz) the Character of a Puritan.

The Church, formerly the pure Temple of Di∣ine Adoration, and the Place where True Re∣ligion was Taught; the Gospel of our Lord Jesus Propagated, Youth Catechised and Instructed, and God Honoured; now became the Theatre of Strife, filled with the Farce Additional Ceremo∣nies Unprescribed by the Connon, and with con∣tinued Railery at those, who were not able to le∣vel their Principles to the loosness of the Times.

The Church-Yards were Throng'd every Lord's Day with the Youths of the Country, just like a Market, place or a Fair; who stood ready, assoon as the blessing was out of the Minister's Mouth, to call as Loudly for that Curse that God has pro∣nounced against those that break his Command∣ments: The Joyful shout of the Congregation Singing Praises to God at the Conclusion of his Worship, was immediately Eccho'd from without, by the Rabble shouting to the Ring, and to the Dance, to the Wrestling and the Cudgel playing; and the Ministers who had but just before Reve∣rently prayed to God for the People, joyns in pro∣voking God with them. No sooner was the Ser∣vice Ended, but the Bells began to Ring, the Ale-House open, the People, fall to Dancing, and Revelling—the blessed Equivolent to Queen Elizabeth's Reformation.

The Sober Religious, Godly Family's who with their old Ministers, abhored this way of Prophaning God's Day, Retired; shut themselves up in their Houses, and spent the rest of the Day in Reading God's Word, Instructing their Chil∣dren and Servants, and Praying with their Fami∣lies; for which they were Damn'd as Schismaticks, Reproch'd as Puritans, and Precise People their Windows often broke, and they Branded as Dis∣loyal,
and Disaffected, being they would not o∣bey the Commands of their Prince, to go to the Devil the Shortest Way.
Two things had their beginning at this Period; and tho' I do not descend to the Proof of it, for want of room in this Tract, yet I offer my self to prove the Fact at any time.

Q.P: 1. Dissenting began here; and had it not been for this Abominable Step, there had been no such thing known in this Nation, as a breaking off from the Church; For the Old Puritans, al∣tho' they did Dislike some things, yet they made it a point of Conscience, not to break off in Communion from the Church; and probably never had broken off, if this Vil Attempt, of setting up an Allowed Prophana tion of the Lord's Day had not been made and they push'd at to join in it; which the refus'd to do, from the very same Principle that the Glorious Mrtyrs in Queen Mary Days refused Popery; at the price of their Lives, and the Penalty of Fire and Faggot.

2. The Deluge of Impiety and Licentiousness be∣gan here, which has since overspread the Face of this Nation; and here the Convoca∣tion might have found it, If they had thought fit to have Trac'd it farder back. And a these Reverend Gentlemen, cannot be igno rant of the Fact, there is no doubt, but th Knowledge they had of its being to be found here, was one principal Reason, why the Trac'd it no farther back than the late Rebe∣lion.

DIV1.P:
Come we next to Enquire Concerning the Pe∣riod where these Gentlemen have placed it (Viz.) The late Rebellion; from which it ma
be allowed it had an Addition; tho' I cannot al∣low the Source or beginning to be there, as the Convocation has alledged; Now, tho' in strict Rea∣soning, this is nothing to the purpose; because, when People are Tracing a Stream to its Source, the additional Channels that may add to and en∣large that Stream, are nothing to the Main En∣quiry; (viz.) its Source or beginning, which is the Question in hand; yet having first prov'd un∣denyably, that the Source or Original of these things was not rightly placed; and this I think is plain, I shall not stick to grant them, that those beginnings of Mischief, tho' risen to a Deluge be∣fore the said War, yet receiv'd a Great Addition from the Accident of the said Rebellion.

But then it would be Natural to Enquire from which Party, or from which Side, either of King or Parliament, during that Unnatural Re∣bellion, the Deluge of Impiety aforesaid, receiv'd the greatest Addition: And tho' the mighty Cry of Hypocrisy and Puritanism which was raised against the Parliament Party, seems to carry an acknowledgement with it, that they had at least a greater shew of Religion, and restraint of Man∣ners than ordinary, whether sincere or not, is not to my purpose; Yet it must be own'd, the King's Party were no Hypocrites, but gave themselves a Liberty in all manner of avowed Wickedness, Blasphemy, Oaths, Drunkenness, and Debauch∣ry; which all their Writers acknowledge, and the King himself often spoke of with regret, but could never restrain: This had certainly some share in the Addition to the Deluge aforesaid; since tho' there may be but little True Religion, where there is a great show of it, yet there is cer∣tainly less, where there is no show at all: And it
is better for a Nation, if one of the two Misfor∣tunes must befall it, to have a false appearance of Religion, than no Vestiges or appearance of Re∣ligion at all; For they that pretend to Religion, tho' falsly, will put on a shew of Sanctity, and some appearance of Morals, whereas the other with their pretences to Religion, cast off all pre∣tences to Sobreity of Manners, or to the Rule of Humanity it self.

Much of this was the Case in the late Unnatu∣ral War; one Side pretended to Religion, 'tis nothing to me in this Enquiry, whether they did any more than pretend or no, let that lie as it will but the other pretended to nothing, but gave an entire Loose to all manner of Profaneness and Impiety.

Now whether of these Contributed most to the Encreasing the Deluge, for that it was a De∣luge before, has been clearly proved, of Impiety and Licentiousness which is broke in upon this Nati∣on, is for any body to determine.
The Sum of the Matter therefore seems to lie thus, and had the Convocation thought fit to have acted Impartially, they would have Con∣cluded it so.
DIV1.Q:
That the Original and Source of that Deluge of Impiety and Licentiousness which is broken in upon this Nation, is to be found in the letting loose the People to all manner of Liberty, in the Prophanation of the Lords Day, and taking off the Restraint of the Laws from them, by the Book of Sports; by which, the Wicked Na ture of Men being left to its own full swing, run out into all manner of Ecess, and that the same being Encreased on both sides, during the late Ʋnnatural Rebellion, has produc'd in the
Minds of Men, a disregard to the very ap∣pearances of Religion, and is ended in a Spirit of down right Libertinism and Profaneness, which have ever since too much prevail'd upon us.
DIV1.P: Had the Reverend the Committee thought fit to have given this honest account of the thing, Her Majesty had then had a True and Im∣partial State of Religion in the Nation, and all Men would have acquiesced in the Justice of it, as what every good Man acknowledges with regret.

But this is Prevaricating with Her Majesty, giv∣ing a partial Representation of the Thing, assign∣ing it to a false, and apparently wrong Original, concealing the Truth, and endeavouring to A∣buse Her Majesty, by Loading those People with the Beginnings and Cause of this Mischief, who had no hand in it; and confidently giving such a Reason for their fixing it there, as consists nei∣ther with Justice to the Case it self, or good Man∣ners to the QƲEEN; seing to say they have Traced it but so far, is to imply, they did not think themselves obliged to Trace it thoroughly for Her Majesties Satisfaction, but so far only as might be for their Purpose, in imposing upon her Majesty, and the whole Nation.

After having thus found them Deficient in the Searching or Tracing this Evil to its True Source; it could not reasonably be expected they should give a True Account of its Progress, or Restraint, neither indeed have they done so.

In the First Place, the Representation drops the Subject, and as a thing, which indeed they foresaw would lie too heavy at last, where they did not desire to feel the weight, they leave the
Subject of their Inexpressible Grief (viz.) the De∣luge of Impiety, Licentiousness and Profaneness, and lay the whole stress of their Complaint, upon the Publishing Blasphemous and Heretical Books & Notions in the World, in prejudice of the Fun damentall Doctrine of the Christian Faith.
But they Err in the first Step, Concerning what has already, and would again put a check to this Evil, (viz.) Laying it all upon Restrain∣ing the Liberty of the Press.

This is so Gross a Mistake, and is aproved so by Experience and by the Temper and Customs of the People of this Nation, that on the contra∣ry, the Liberty of the Press, so far as it is Legal∣ly a Liberty, both is and may be the best step to pull down and put a stop to Error, Heresie and Blasphemous Principles.

The Christian Religion, which is founded u∣pon Truth, and seeks Demonstration, has in all Ages Flourished by the Liberty of the Press; and the Restraining the Press at this Day in Popish Countries, by the great Labour of the Inquisiti∣on, is the Reason why the Reformation can get no footing in Spain, in America, in Portugal, or in Italy. It has in all those Places been the Com∣plaint of the Protestants, as it was of St. Augusting in former times, That Christians were not al∣lowed to Defend their Doctrine by Writing, and by force of Reason and Argument; believing that the Christian, as also the Protestant Faith, would ever gain ground of Error and Heresies, if they were admitted to Print freely, and disperse their Writings in its Defence; and Publish their Expo∣sitions; by which the Eyes of the Common Peo∣ple would be Enlighned, and their Understand∣ings
freed from the Mists of Darkness, Supersti∣tion and Error.

This was the very Case in the first Reformati∣on in England; and the Papists finding that the Doctrine of the Lollards, as they call them, or Waldenses, spread among the Common People, by the Reading of the Books of that Famous Man John Wicklif, they immediatly applyed them∣selves to the same Work now proposed (and perhaps for the same Reason) (viz.) putting a Restraint upon the Press, and destroying all those Books, as far as they could lay their hands upon them.

Our Clergy are not insensible, that putting Legal Restraints upon the Press in Spain, and in Portugal, is the Reason that the Bible is kept from the Laity, and the People kept from the Know∣ledge of the Scriptures; and the having but an Heretical Book in a Family in those Countries, is enough to bring the Master of that Family in∣to the Inquisition.

Therefore there is no doubt but putting such Restraints upon the Press, would suppress very much the PRINTING: But I must tell them, it might not suppress at all the Publishing those Blasphemous Errors of which they now Com∣plain.

Q.P: 1. Because they could by no Power in Eng∣land, ever expect a Law to prevent Peoples Reading such Books, or keeping them in their Houses, they could never get leave to Search Houses for them, and punish the People where they were found; unless they could set up a kind of Protestant Inquisition here.

2. The Temper of our People being so Curi∣ous after Books, and particularly so after such as are Prohibit or forbid, the Searching for such Books, would be the readiest Step they could take, to make People put a Va∣lue upon them, Enquire for them, and Pur∣chase them, whatever they Cost: As was Experienced by the Papists, in the Case of Wickliff, Bilney, and Tindal's Books, in the 14th, 15th, and 16th Century.

DIV1.P: But what are these Legal Restraints they want We may very well understand what they mean, by their telling us what the Success was of those they had. It is Evident, the Legal Restraint they had, was a LICENSER; that is, a Tyrant of the Press. This was crush'd after∣ward, on the following Reasons.

Q.P: 1. Because it was Illegal in its Nature, being against the Right of the English Nation, to be forbidden freedom of Speech, in their own Lawful and Just Defence. Since were a Book ever so Necessary, or Just, Useful or Profitable in a Publick on a Private Case, it lay in the Breast of such LICENSER to Suppress it, and Silence the Author.

2. Because the Management of the English Government so often shifting Hands, it may come to pass, that the Press may come whol∣ly into such Hands, which may put the same Oppressive Injurious Restraint upon the CHURCH, as was likely to have hap∣pen'd, if King James had continued.

DIV1.P: 3. Because it Deprives the Subject of making the National Oppressions and Grievances, when such happen, known to the People.
4. If error and Heresie should ever get the redominancy in the Government in England which God forbid) the True Religion may Suffer the same Yoak.
But after all, we say farther.

Q.P: 1. There are Sufficient Legal Restraints upon the Press already; since every Error, Schism and Heresie maintained in Print, may be Prosecuted by our Laws, may be condemn'd and the Person Censured for the same, and Punished, whether Author, or Publisher, or both, as is evident in the Governments daily Prosecuting Seditious Books; the same Law being in Force against Heretical Blas∣phemous Libels; and the Fault is rather the Church not putting such Laws in Executi∣on, and duly Prosecuting such People, ra∣ther than want of Laws to Prosecute upon.

2. This is all a kind of a Tacit Acknowledg∣ment of the weakness of the Christian Do∣ctrine, or the Incapacity of the Church of England's Divines to Defend it; and the Jealousie they seem to have, that Error and Heresie should get Ground of them by Dis∣putation. The contrary to which is, what our Divines of the Church of England have all along pretended to; witness Dr. Calamy's Challenge to the Dissenters, wherein he says, All the Church of England Divines de∣sire is, to have People come fairly and pro∣pose their Doubts, and make due Enquiry after Truth, that they may hear what both Sides have to say, and Determine for them∣selves.

DIV1.P:
But this Pretence of having the Press Restrain∣is Declaring the Church, of England is not
able to stand her Ground against Heresie an Schism in Matters of Dispute; and therefor like Monsieur Jurieu at the Hague, Disputi with Mr. S—is, when he found his Adversa was too hard for him, he Petition'd the STATE that Mr. S—is might not be permitted to Wri any more against him. Or, as the Examin∣lately against the Medley; who finding himself Oppress'd with the Medly's Arguments, Criout to have the Ministry punish him for it.

Just thus the Fam'd Dr. Calamy (a∣bove-mentioned) did by Mr. Delaun who Accepted the Doctor's Challenge which, as I have Noted, he made t all the Dissenters, to come and have their Doubts fairly Discussed. But when the Dr. found his Challenge was Accepted, by a Man of Superior Learn∣ing to himself, Caused the Book to be Crused at the Printing-House, by the same Legal Restraint upon the Press which the Convocation now are Desi∣ring, and his Antagonist was most Ef∣fectually Silenced, by Perishing in a Jayle.
DIV1.Q:
This was the way that Stephen Gard∣ner Disputed with Archbisho Cranmer, Bonner, with John Phil pot; Bishop Laud, with Prinn and
Bastiwick; Calamy, with Delaune; Obadiah Walker, with Dr. Hough; King James, with the Seven Bishops, and Sacheverel with D' Foe. And this it seems is the way our Con∣vocation earnestly desires to Dis∣pute with the Schismaticks.
DIV1.P: But they that know the Strength of the Protestant Doctrine, the Orthodox Foundation of the Church of England Principles, and the Ability of her D I∣VINES to Defend it, Contemn the Assistance of Force to Suppress Error; and to Answer Arguments with Vio∣lence.

For this Reason, they have on all Occasions, powerfully Resisted, and Successfully also, all the Errors of the Times, to this Day; and have now set about that most Effectual Step to fix a good Foundation of RELIGION in Posterity, as the best Means to fix them in the Truth, and Fortifie them against Heresie; and this is, the Early Instruction of Youth, Breeding Chil∣dren up in a clear Understanding of the
first Principles of the Christian Religi∣on; which, if well pursued, there would be less Danger of the Corruption of Er∣ror taking Place among them. And this will do more towards Establishing the Minds of the People, against the Contagion of Heresie, than all the Empty Negatives of keeping Ill Book out of their Hands.

To this, they might have joyned a steady Prosecution of the Law against every Erroneous Book, either in the Name o themselves, or in the Name and Autho∣rity of the Government, which no doubt would agree to it; which if Profecuted, as the Law does already su∣ficiently Direct and allow; would in a few Years be totally and effectually Discouraged, and Suppress'd.

One Thing more might be added here; and which, next to the Instruction of the Youth, is the most Effectual Step that can be taken; towards the taking away all Danger of the Peoples being Debauched into Error; and the Omis∣sion of which, perhaps is at present the Chief Reason why they are so easily led
away from the Church. And this is the Effectual Reformation of the Clergy of the Church of England; which howe∣ver the Convocation have thought fit to leave wholly out of their Representation of the State of Religion, is the Great thing which is now wanting, to Sup∣press Flagrant Errors, Blasphemies, Heresies, and Atheistical Writings; and the want of which, is at present the Grief of all Good Man in the Church of England, as well as the Triumph of her Enemies.

I am not here preparing a Satyr upon the Vices of the Clergy of the Church of England; the Author of this is one, who rather Mourns for the want of their Reformation, than Rejoyees over their Falling; but at the same time▪ cannot but wonder how the Reverend Convocation could leave it out of a Re∣presentation of the State of RELIGION; especially if they had a Design by it, to have a Stop put to the Deluge of Im∣piety and Licentiousness, which is broke∣n upon us, and which, the Reforming
the Clergy, is the first and best Step t Deliver us from.

Wherefore, if the Author Lives to pursue this Argument, he shall E deavour to lay down the True Method how the State of Religion, which is present thus Declining, may be Re∣stored; the Number of Dissenters Le∣sened, the Blasphemy, Errors and In∣fidelity of the Age Suppress'd, without Running such Lengths as the Represen∣tation seems to Aim at.
